title: Aesthetic tweaks
body: Set the same (dark) background for all demos for uniformity. Also changed some slider ranges so that it did not go below 30 fps or so for the NumDot versions.
author: 20akshay00

comments.body: Thanks!

title: draw using gpu particles
body: Draw fireflies using GPUParticles2D. As it stands, it also passes position data every frame, so a dynamic simulation can be displayed with the existing performance as well.
author: 20akshay00

comments.body: Looks good, thanks!

title: Selection menu for demo projects
body:
Added a selection menu for the projects, displaying some information for each one on a card. Each demo project has an associated `metadata.json` now. This PR also changes all root scenes of demos to `main.tscn` for consistency. 

This now packages the entire demo folder as a playable game, suitable for a web build to share with people. We should consider automating the build process and hosting on itch through Github actions as well.
author: 20akshay00

comments.body: Awesome, thanks!

title: Minor changes to SIRS demo
body:
- Added visual tweaks to match GD and ND versions. 
- The visual size of the grid is now fixed for all N values, capped at 300x300 which is when the drawing throttles the fps anyways despite numdot performing well. Not sure how to improve this.
- Changed convolution kernel to not include the site itself.
author: 20akshay00

comments.body: Thanks!

title: Replace drawing in wave demo with polylines instead of circles
body: Not sure if there's any noticeable performance boost, but it makes more sense to plot a line anyways.
author: 20akshay00

comments.body: Thanks!

title: SIRS model
body:
Add demo of SIRS model, a demonstration of disease spread using cellular automata rules. Currently, the GDScript implementation outperforms the NumDot one by a large margin. This is likely due to the numerous conversion calls of `to_godot_array()` and back when computing the nearest neighbours of a cell. This can be rectified if a `convolve2d` function is exposed by NumDot. 

Regardless, this PR is submitted to serve as a test case to further optimize NumDot calls and until it is fixed, it remains as a warning of the inefficiency of type conversions.

(Also made some minor changes to the wave equation demo to be more consistent and avoid clashes with other demos.)
author: 20akshay00

comments.body: Looks good, thank you!

title: Wave equation demo
body: Added wave equation demo in /demos/. Also set the project expand mode to `canvas_items`.
author: 20akshay00

comments.body: Looks good, thanks!

title: add remaining comparison operators
body: Almost closes #34 . `nonzero` needs to be implemented.
author: 20akshay00

comments.body: Looks good, thanks!
We'll leave nonzero for a later day since it returns indices, a format not currently returned by NumDot.

title: Math functions
body:
Adds a bunch of basic math functions.

- asin, acos, atan, sinh, cosh, tanh, asinh, acosh, atanh: Closes #29.
- minimum, maximum, rad2deg, deg2rad: Partially covers #35. 
- logical_or, logical_not: Partially covers #52.
author: 20akshay00

comments.body: Looks good! I'll add the according documentation and includes post merge. Thanks!

title: Compile issues on Windows
body: Changed a stray `nullptr_t` to be called through the `std` namespace and added some instructions to use MinGW to compile on Windows.
author: 20akshay00

comments.body: Looks good, thanks!

hey @Ivorforce,
while building the project I was running into this issue
`In file included from src/ndarray.cpp:1:
In file included from src/ndarray.h:23:
src/vatensor/varray.h:14:10: fatal error: 'xtensor/xarray.hpp' file not found
#include "xtensor/xarray.hpp"           // for xarray_adaptor
         ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
1 error generated.
scons: *** [src/ndarray.os] Error 1
scons: building terminated because of errors.`

I have written a basic structure for the rounding functions but can't test because of this failure. Can you help me out with this?
TIA
Hi, try compiling again. It usually fails on the first try. (see #23)
still getting the same error, I see this is a recent change

I think the includes may fail on any (random) xtensor include. Due to #23, it does not reliably set up the 3 dependencies (xtl, xtensor, xsimd).

Try the following in your command line manually:

```
# in numdot folder
cd xtl/build && cmake ../ && cmake --install . --prefix .
# back to numbot folder
cd xsimd/build && cmake ../ -DENABLE_XTL_COMPLEX=1 -Dxtl_DIR='../xtl/build/ && cmake --install . --prefix .
# back to numdot folder
cd xtensor/build && cmake ../ -DXTENSOR_USE_XSIMD=1 -Dxtl_DIR='../xtl/build/' -Dxsimd_DIR='../xsimd/build/' && cmake --install . --prefix .
```

This basically replicates what SConstruct is supposed to do.
Anyway, I was able to run it. Compiled fine without any tests, code looks good. I'll adjust includes and docs post-merge. Thanks!

Reading up on the differences between rint and nearbyint, i'm deleting nearbyint and using nearbyint for the rint implementation. As i understand, rint raises when it actually had to perform rounding, which is not really useful in vectorized cases.

@Krishn1412 I was attempting to build this on Windows 10 w/ mingw and faced the same issue. I ended up resolving it by manually building the three dependencies as mentioned above, and then removed those subcommands from the SConstruct file before running it again.

edit: we traced the issue to the fact that powershell doesn't recognize `&&` and deletes the tmp file (xtl.hpp for example) when that command fails.
I just removed the cmake steps from SConstruct and just added the include dirs to the project. Found no difference so far. Hopefully this eliminates these issues for good.
yup makes sense, we won't be needing rint here
